user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.

revision_history.draft:
# Kitchen at 7, Before the Wake

The coffeemaker clicks its cycle on.
You leave the mug where it is,
second cup, still warm from December,
and pour the milk in quiet
the way you've poured it since October,
which is to say with such practiced aim
that the pitcher catches on the rim
and releases only that exact
surge of air between your breaths.

The kitchen window is the kind of dark
that has no name yet — before dawn
has any money in its pocket to pay for light.
You wait for the faucet. Wait
the way you wait when someone's already
home, which is not with urgency,
which is not with anything like
longing. Just the feeling that
the house expects you.

The radiator ticks its metal legs
against the baseboard every thirteen seconds.
I know because I've counted it
from your side of the bed, where you sleep
on your back with one hand under a pillow
holding what looks like a small country,
and the other fisted at your side
the way hands keep themselves when someone
hasn't decided yet whether they're needed.

The water is almost there.
You don't look up until it is,
until the cup fills in the time
it takes me to exhale through the nose,
that particular sound we both know —
not a sigh, not a request for more,
just the animal need to clear the air.

You carry it down the hall barefoot,
mug cradled like a thing of yours
since birth. The floorboards
speak their one syllable word
each step you take and I can hear them
through the door although you make no sound
opening anything — just stand
in the doorway, mug still full,
the steam already thinning.

You tip it an inch toward my face.
I don't flinch. You pour without being asked,
the way you've always poured:
not generosity, not accident,
just a body that has learned
where another's mouth will be.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The domestic specificity is the engine here, and it works. The mug "still warm from December" — that's a real detail with emotional weight because it resists sentimentality by refusing to linger on warmth-as-connection. The water faucet scene is genuinely strong: "the feeling that / the house expects you." This line earns its abstraction because every other line around it is concrete. The radiator ticking "against the baseboard every thirteen seconds" — the precision of the timing doesn't feel like decoration; it's observed, and that observation is what makes it credible.

The barefoot pouring in at the end is a powerful closing image: quiet, private, functional. The final line ("not generosity, not accident, / just a body that has learned") lands because the poem has built toward it with enough sensory material to anchor the philosophy.

The enjambment is doing real work throughout — "you pour the milk in quiet" breaks at "quiet," isolating that word so it carries the weight of absence before the next line arrives with the pitcher sound. That's good craft.

### What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 27–30):**
> Just the animal need to clear the air.
>
> You pour without being asked,
> the way you've always poured:
> not generosity, not accident,
> just a body that has learned
> where another's mouth will be.

This is the poem explaining its own meaning. The first two lines of this passage are already in the poem; the last three restate them as commentary. Cut or rewrite entirely: "the way you've always poured" is doing what the closing line does better, so neither should exist. Let the pouring speak for itself.

**Redundancy (lines 19–20):**
> The kitchen window is the kind of dark
> that has no name yet — before dawn
> has any money in its pocket to pay for light.

"Dark" appears twice in two lines, and "no name yet" / "no money in its pocket" is a personification that dilutes what could be a precise sensory claim. Either make the image sharper or cut it entirely; both clauses soften rather than sharpen.

**Cliché proximity (line 27):**
> I can hear them
> through the door although you make no sound

This reads almost like a greeting-card line — "you make no sound" is close to "I heard you anyway." Make the silence do something stranger, more particular. What does the sound actually resemble? The floorboards speak one syllable each time — extend that logic.

**Direction**

The revision direction: strip the three lines of explanation from near the end entirely. Trust the image of the barefoot pouring into the face. If true love is proven by action, let the last twelve lines carry the entire poem's meaning without

revision_history.draft:
The coffeemaker clicks its cycle on.
You leave the mug where it is,
second cup, still warm from December,
and pour the milk in quiet
the way you've poured it since October—
that exact surge, wrist slightly bent,
pitcher catching on the rim.

The kitchen window is dark
with no name yet. Dawn hasn't
opened its eyes. You wait
for the faucet. Wait the way
you wait when someone's home: not urgent,
not wanting anything more than
the house holds open without saying.

Radiator legs tick their small metal feet
every thirteen seconds against the baseboard.
I've counted it from your side of the bed—
you sleep on your back, one hand
curling around what looks like a country,
fist held at your temple, the other stiff
at your side. Hands like that.

The water is almost there.
You don't look up until it is,
the cup filling in the time
it takes me to exhale through the nose—
that particular sound we both know
but never name between ourselves.

Down the hall barefoot, mug cradled
like a thing you've held since birth.
Floorboards speak their one word each step:
snap-tap-snap-tap. I can hear them
through the door although you make no sound,
just stand in the doorway, full cup,
steam thinning already.

You tilt it toward my face an inch—
I don't flinch. You pour without being asked,
the way your hand has learned
where my mouth will be. Not kindness.
Not accident either. Just practice.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The domestic specificity is the poem's engine, and it works. "Second cup, still warm from December" — that detail resists sentimentality by refusing to linger on warmth-as-connection; it earns its place through restraint. The radiator ticking "against the baseboard every thirteen seconds" is observed with enough precision to feel credible rather than decorative. The barefoot pouring in at the end is a powerful closing image: quiet, private, functional.

The enjambment is doing real work throughout — "you pour the milk in quiet" breaks at "quiet," isolating that word so it carries the weight of absence before the next line arrives with the pitcher sound. That's good craft.

### What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 27–30):**
> I can hear them
> through the door although you make no sound.
> Not urgency, not wanting anything more than
> the house holds open without saying.

"Make no sound" is close to "I heard you anyway," a greeting-card move. The closing philosophical explanation ("not urgency / not wanting anything") does what the image of barefoot pouring into at face already accomplishes — so cut or rewrite entirely: let the pouring speak for itself, and trust the silence.

**Redundancy (lines 19–20):**
> The kitchen window is dark
> with no name yet. Dawn hasn't
> opened its eyes.
>
> The kitchen window is the kind of dark
> that has no name yet — before dawn
> has any money in its pocket to pay for light.

"Dark" appears twice, and "no name yet" / "no money in its pocket" is personification that dilutes what could be a precise sensory claim. Either make the image sharper or cut it entirely; both clauses soften rather than sharpen.

**Cliché proximity (line 27):**
> Floorboards speak their one syllable word
> each step you take and I can hear them

This reads almost like a greeting-card line — "you make no sound." Make the silence do something stranger, more particular. What does the sound actually resemble? The floorboards speak one syllable each time — extend that logic.

**Weak line break (line 26):**
> Steam thinning already.
>
> You tip it an inch toward my face.

"Steam thinning already" is a complete enough image to stand as its own line, but the break creates no tension or surprise — there's nothing the reader doesn't expect from the scene. Consider whether the line should merge with what follows, or sharpen the trailing edge of steam into something more surprising.

**Direction**

The revision direction: **cut lines 27–30 entirely**, trust the barefoot pouring at the end as the poem's closing gesture. **Compress and sharpen the window/dawn

revision_history.draft:
The drip-cycle clicks its slow
reps against the mug where it sits,
second cup, still warm enough to darken
the kitchen table's oak. You add milk—
not pouring but pressing the pitcher's spout
against the rim until a dent holds it there,
that small arrested column finding the edge.

The window is dark with sleep.
Dawn hasn't moved an inch along its ledges.
You wait for the faucet like waiting
for someone you expect to stay:
no urgency, no fidgeting, just the table
holding your cup the way a hand holds a stone.

Radiator legs tick their small metal feet
against the baseboard every thirteen seconds—
I've counted it from here, from under the sheets,
your back flat, one hand curled around what looks like
the shape of somewhere, the other angled wrong.
Hands like that. Stiff like that.

The water is almost there. You don't look up
until it pools above the rim and you tilt—
a half-inch drop before your wrist releases it,
that particular stillness before something falls.

Through the door I hear barefoot steps
on hardwood: snap-tap-snap, each floorboard
saying its one thing, which is just to be.
You stop at the doorway. Full cup.
Steam thinning already into the window's dark.

You lower it toward my face an inch—
I don't flinch. You pour without being asked,
the way your hand has learned what I can't name:
not practice either but the place where things
become a little softer without anyone deciding to.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The final section is the strongest work here. "Barefoot steps / on hardwood: snap-tap-snap, each floorboard / saying its one thing" — that line earns its place through rhythmic precision and plainness of diction. The barefoot pouring at the end ("You pour without being asked") lands because it's grounded in a specific physical act rather than explained.

The radiator legs ticking "every thirteen seconds against the baseboard" is observed with enough specificity to feel like an actual sensory memory, not a decorative detail. That precision is the poem's core method — small, unromanticized things that only two people who have been together for years would notice.

### What Isn't Working

**Redundancy / structural bloat (lines 27–30):**
> Through the door I hear barefoot steps
> on hardwood: snap-tap-snap-tap. I can hear them
> through the door although you make no sound.
> Not urgency, not wanting anything more than
> the house holds open without saying.

This passage explains what it already showed. "Not urgency" and "without saying" are editorializing — they tell the reader how to feel about something that required zero explanation from image. Cut or compress entirely: let the pouring speak for itself. The barefoot tapping is already doing the work of quiet presence; "I can hear them" adds nothing.

**Cliché proximity / weak line break (line 26):**
> Steam thinning already.
>
> You tilt — a half-inch drop before your wrist releases it,
> that particular stillness before something falls.

"Steam thinning already" is close to the "no name yet" passage earlier — vague, decorative, and self-explanatory. The break after "already" creates no tension or surprise; steam thinning is its own action. Consider merging this into the pouring line or sharpening what follows so the trailing edge of steam becomes more surprising.

**Abstraction / abstraction-as-philosophy (lines 19–20):**
> You wait for the faucet like waiting
> for someone you expect to stay:
> no urgency, no fidgeting, just the table
> holding your cup the way a hand holds a stone.

"Waiting for someone you expect to stay" is emotional summary where an image was needed. "Holding your cup the way a hand holds a stone" is a simile that collapses into cliché — cold, heavy, unyielding. Replace with something as plain and specific as what precedes it: coffee poured from milk in a mug.

**Direction**

The revised draft should be 15–20 lines at most. Cut any line that explains the image rather than extending or sharpening it. Trust the domestic details — the radiator legs, the floorboard clicks, the barefoot tapping, the pouring itself

revision_history.draft:
The drip-cycle clicks its slow
reps against the mug where it sits,
second cup, still warm enough to darken
the kitchen's dark—sleep thickened here,
the oak table holding warmth like a held breath.

You add milk—
not pouring but pressing the pitcher's spout
against the rim until a dent holds it there,
that small arrested column finding the edge.

The window is dark with sleep.
Dawn hasn't moved an inch along its ledges.
The faucet ticks its thirteen-second pulse
against the baseboard, each leg ticking
its one thing: metal on metal, repeating.

Your back flat. One hand curled around what looks like
the shape of somewhere, the other angled wrong—
hands like that. Stiff like that.

Almost there—the water and you
holding still until it pools above the rim,
then your wrist releases in a half-inch drop,
that particular quiet before something falls.

Through the door I hear barefoot steps
on hardwood: snap-tap-snap, each floorboard
saying its one thing—just to be.
You stop at the doorway. Full cup.
Steam thinning already into the window's dark.

You lower it toward my face an inch—
I don't flinch. You pour without being asked,
the way your hand has learned what I can't name:
not practice either but the place where things
become a little softer without anyone deciding to.

final_poem:
The drip-cycle clicks its slow
reps against the mug where it sits,
second cup, still warm enough to darken
the kitchen's dark—sleep thickened here,
the oak table holding warmth like a held breath.

You add milk—
not pouring but pressing the pitcher's spout
against the rim until a dent holds it there,
that small arrested column finding the edge.

The window is dark with sleep.
Dawn hasn't moved an inch along its ledges.
The faucet ticks its thirteen-second pulse
against the baseboard, each leg ticking
its one thing: metal on metal, repeating.

Your back flat. One hand curled around what looks like
the shape of somewhere, the other angled wrong—
hands like that. Stiff like that.

Almost there—the water and you
holding still until it pools above the rim,
then your wrist releases in a half-inch drop,
that particular quiet before something falls.

Through the door I hear barefoot steps
on hardwood: snap-tap-snap, each floorboard
saying its one thing—just to be.
You stop at the doorway. Full cup.
Steam thinning already into the window's dark.

You lower it toward my face an inch—
I don't flinch. You pour without being asked,
the way your hand has learned what I can't name:
not practice either but the place where things
become a little softer without anyone deciding to.
